instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1466: What is A1466? A1466 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Early 2015, 2017, Mid 2012, Mid 2013, Early 2014 with EMC 2925, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00165, 820-3209, 820-3437..
definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no power
threads.message:
Hi,
I have an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B with no power
it has green light, fan speed, pulls 500mA from bench PSU, but no usb activity.

L7320:
1= 1,49V
2=1.74V

L7310:
1= 1,49V
2=1.74V

L7630:
1=0.9V
2=1V

Can you help?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no power
threads.message:
What's <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> ?
Do you also get <SIGNAL>PCH_CLK32K_RTCX1</SIGNAL> (32kHz) ?

Look around <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> / <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> for damage/corrosion

Also check <CHIP>U8005</CHIP> for corrosion

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no power
threads.message:
Hi Paul,
Here is the colour blind guy from your FlexBoard. Tks for the help...
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>  = 3.3V
<CHIP>U6100</CHIP> / <CHIP>U1900</CHIP>  seams to be ok but I found around Y1905 it has corrosion and signs of liquid contact. I'll replace those resistors, caps and also Y1905
<CHIP>U8005</CHIP> seams to also be ok

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no power
threads.message:
Ah, small world there.  Hope the new releases of FlexBV are helping you adjust colours more to your liking, especially now with the colour adjustable parts ability.

Did you get 32kHz on pin 12 of <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> ?

Is the corrosion seemingly from liquid ingress or more just that typical surface corrosion that happens over time just naturally ?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no power
<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no power
threads.message:
I get an average 30khz and 40 max, on  <SIGNAL>PCH_CLK32K_RTCX1</SIGNAL> (<CHIP>U1900</CHIP>).
The corrosion seams to be from liquid contact (shal i remove those components right now)?

[B][USER=682]2informaticos[/USER][/B]
I do have 3.3V on  <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no power
threads.message:
RTC block is OK, if machine turns on.

Did you try known good BIOS?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no power
threads.message: No, I haven't tried a known good BIOS yet. Shall I do it now) , or test something else first?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no power
threads.message:
I just notice that all test points near Y1905, includind <SIGNAL>PCH_HSIO_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> test point, are missing. 
Can it be it? Where is the best choice to jumper it?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no power
threads.message:
Hi,
I rebuild the tracks of the test points near Y1905 to the <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> and it started to work.
Tks.
